Title: The Diseases of Modern Life: Nineteenth-Century Perspectives

Abstract: This project, titled "The Diseases of Modern Life: Nineteenth-Century Perspectives," seeks to explore how the Victorian era conceptualized and addressed the health challenges associated with modern life. Centered on Benjamin Ward Richardson's seminal work "Diseases of Modern Life" (1876), the project will investigate a broad spectrum of conditions, including diseases from worry and mental strain, lifestyle diseases such as alcohol and narcotics abuse, environmental pollution diseases, and more. By focusing on the interplay between literature, science, and medicine, this research aims to uncover the connections between physiological, psychological, and social health or disease. The proposed work will adopt a holistic and integrative Victorian vision, utilizing cross-disciplinary scholarship to offer innovative insights into modernity's health challenges.

Through a meticulous examination of how these diseases were perceived and addressed in the 19th century, the project seeks to produce new ground-breaking scholarship that can redefine our understanding of modern health issues. It also aims to break down the barriers between psychiatric, environmental, and literary history, fostering a deeper, more comprehensive understanding of how society has grappled with the health consequences of rapid industrialization and modernization. This interdisciplinary approach promises to yield groundbreaking outcomes that can contribute significantly to contemporary discussions on public health and the impact of modern life on well-being.
